speaker: Ron Paul
vclaim: "The prices are rising. Unemployment continues to rise."
date: stated on May 5, 2011 in a presidential debate:
title: Ron Bull says prices are increasing and unemployment continues to increase.
text: Ron Bull is flirting with the sound of the abdomen. :: During the first 2012 presidential debate in South Carolina on Thursday, the Republic of Texas said that the economy would suffer President Barack Obama ' s efforts to re-election. "My theory is that people vote from their belly because whether they're hungry or not or have jobs and need things, and that's why people vote." "We're in big trouble. Prices rise, unemployment continues to rise." We decided to check whether both prices and unemployment are rising. Let's start with the first. Cheryl Abbott, an economist at the United States Bureau of Labour Statistics, told us that prices are almost always rising because of inflation - the question is whether prices have been increasing at a faster rate lately. And the answer is yes. According to the Consumer Price Index (CPI) developed by the United States Labour Statistics Office, the inflation rate has been accelerating over a year since November 2010, when it was 1.1 per cent. The most recent OIOS data was from March, when the inflation rate was 2.7 per cent. Abbott said that the rise in prices was "due almost entirely to gasoline prices." He got gas prices out of the picture, and changing the rate is nominal, as she said. What about unemployment? The Flash showed up to January 2008, when the unemployment rate was only 5 percent. By October 2009, the proportion was 10.1 per cent. During most of 2010, the unemployment rate was just under 10 per cent, peaking in November at 9.8 per cent. Since then, however, the rate has declined every month, falling to 8.8 per cent in March. To date, when the Office reported that unemployment had risen to 20 points, to 9 percent, in April. Abbott said that this was still high according to historical criteria, but she was babbling with Paul's claim that unemployment was "continuing to rise." And so are we. Paul certainly didn't learn from his family, but he constantly paid for the five months. It was only after Paul explained his point of discussion that the Labour Bureau reported the rise of April. We evaluate the statement half right. On January 16, 2021, Jordan Rachel stated in Tweedda that the minimum wage of $15 per hour would raise the price of taco bill burrito to $38. By Bill McCarthy • January 20, 2012
